profileText: A Representative from Maine; born in Leeds, Maine, August 3, 1801; attended the common schools, and was graduated from Bowdoin College, Brunswick, Maine, in 1823; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Hallowell, Maine, in 1826; member of the State house of representatives in 1841; appointed a member of the Northeastern Boundary Commission in 1842; served in the State senate in 1842; again a member of the State house of representatives in 1846 and 1847; elected as a Whig to the Thirty-first Congress (March 4, 1849-March 3, 1851); died in Hallowell, Kennebec County, Maine, October 17, 1856; interment in Hallowell Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Otis, John. Speech of Hon. John Otis, of Maine, and the minority report of the committee on patents made by him, on The subject of Woodworth's patent for a planing machine, and against the bill for extending that patent. Washington: Printed at the Congressional Globe Office, 1850.

researchRecord.name: 1843, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Otis to Daniel Webster written on January 17, 1843. In the letter, John Otis writes of opinions of the Treaty and settlement. He also writes that most people in Maine are satisfied with the boundary question and that he has had many inquiries about the "disputed boundary fund."

researchRecord.name: In the Correspondence and documents relative to the North Eastern boundary, 1842-1843, 8 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers include reports of the Maine Commissioners, including John Otis.
